_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary                Fort Worth Foam         January 6, 2005

1.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Fort Worth Foam Division of Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, uses Toluene diisocyanate (unspecified isomer)  [Benzene, 1,3-diisocyanatomethyl-] (TDI) as a component of a chemical mix for foam, which is considered a regulated toxin substance by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The same properties that make TDI valuable also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in the handling so as to prevent unnecessary human exposure.  We are dedicated to conducting our operations in compliance with environmental laws and in a safe and responsible manner.  We do not want to put at risk the environment, employees, or the public.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of the employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  We will continue to commit resources and to take appropriate steps to comply with environmental laws.  We may adopt additional standards and procedures beyond those required by law if the company deems them advisable.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which TDI is handled combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility combined with the safe-handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.

2.0    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The primary purpose of this facility is to manufacture, store, and ship Rebond Carpet pad.  The regulated substance handled at this facility is TDI.  The maximum amount of TDI that can be stored at this facility is 171,196 pounds.  See appendix for MSDS on TDI.  Our accident release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed our employees, the public, and the environment by u

se of these chemicals.

3.0    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable Federal and State codes and regulations.  The TDI manufacturer ships and delivers the product using 3rd party equipment and drivers.  We take a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including but not limited to:

?    Operating Procedures
?    Training
?    Compliance Audits
?    Incident Investigation
?    Employee Participation
?    Inspections
As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

?    Inventory control of TDI
?    Two-way communication during off-loading
?    Never leave off-loading area during the unloading process
?    High level alarms with transducers to read level of tanks
?    Work Instructions
?    Review of equipment, including tanks, valves, piping, and locking out of tanks

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  The company and the employees are committed to the standard that the management systems set for the way we do business and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

4.0    Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of TDI in the past five years; therefore the company does not have an accident to report.

5.0    Emergency Response Program

The company maintains a Plant Emergency Organization (PEO) and emergency response plan.  The emergency response program is based upon Leggett & Platt corporate policies, and procedures as outline in LEGGETT & PLATT PERSONNEL & PROPERTY CONSERVATION MANUAL.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the env

ironment during emergency situations.  Response activities are coordinated with the Fort Worth, Texas Fire Department.  Company employees will act to provide incidental response to mitigate a TDI release.  If the event is beyond the scope of an accidental response, employees will evacuate and call the Fort Worth, Texas Fire Department.  The Fort Worth, Texas Fire Department will initiate the community emergency plan for a TDI release.

6.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The company is looking into the addition of carbon drum scrubbers.  The company is continually looking for ways to improve safety.

7.0    Certifications

Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, our Risk Management Program is written to comply with Program Level 2.  The distance to the specified endpoint for the worst-case accidental release scenario may impact the small residential population surrounding the facility.

Within the past five years, the process has had no accidental releases that caused off-site impacts provided in the RMP rule [40 CFR 68.10(b)(1)].  We have taken voluntary measures to improve our operations to minimize potential releases of covered materials in order to protect both our employees and the public.  In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the process, entry within the distance to the specified endpoint may pose a danger to public emergency responders.  Therefore public emergency responders should not enter this area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMPlan.
